inventory.commentary: WordNet senses 8 and 9 refer to proper names and are not included in groups below. 15Mar07 - revised features. ahouston

sense.name: adhesive force between physical entities
sense.examples: How strong is the bond between hydrogen and oxygen atoms in water molecules? The two components used in Crazyglue will form quite a strong bond when combined.

sense.name: attachment, restraint or shackle between physical entities
sense.examples: The bonds that hold my old suitcase together are becoming frayed. The prisoner managed to break the bonds around his ankles.

sense.name: interest-bearing financial certificate
sense.examples: The town is issuing bonds to build the new stadium. John has put a third of his assets into blue chip bonds. She bought a savings bond for her granddaughter.

sense.name: social allegiance
sense.examples: They formed a lifelong bond from their shared wartime experiences. The bond between the two nations was strained by disagreements in foreign policy. There are strong family bonds between John and his cousins in Oregon.

sense.name: bail or surety made against an alleged criminal charge
sense.examples: The judge has posted his bond at 1 million dollars.

sense.name: type of manufactured paper
sense.examples: Don't use such heavy bond in the printer or it may jam. We picked out a pale ecru bond for our music programs.

sense.name: specific arrangement of brick in a wall
sense.examples: Notice the skillful bond on that 19th-century townhouse.

sense.name: goods in a state of government control until duties are paid on them
sense.examples: All these warehouses in the port contain bond destined for Europe and North America.

sense.name: whiskey stored 4 years before bottling, under state control
sense.examples: The labels got washed off John's best bond in the basement, when it flooded.
